bibl.title: Letter from Carlos J. Finlay to Jefferson Randolph Kean, October 2, 1908

div1.p: Finlay discusses sanitation measures taken in response to possible cases of yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from Carlos J. Finlay to Jefferson Randolph Kean, October 2, 1908
div1.opener:
From Dr. Carlos J. Finlay -
República de Cuba
Lajo la Administracion Provisional de los Estados Unidos
Departamento Nacional de Sanidad
--------
Junta Nacional de Sanidad
------
Habana, October 2nd. 10 P. M.
1908
My dear Major Kean:
div1.p:
I thought it would be proper to cable to you
concerning the suspicious case reported at Felton so that you
should not be unprepared if any exaggerated reports are sent by
other parties.

Dr. Thomason does not evidently attach much
importance to the case. He writes to me (Sept. 29) “Found (on ar-
rival) they had one case under observation at Felton but the symp-
toms were such that we have not thought them sufficiently suspi-
cious to bother the Department, with reporting the case even as
a suspect. I however sent Cartaya over Sunday to see the case
and I enclose you the clinical history and his report, from which
you will probably agree with me that there is little ground to
believe the case worthy of alarm. However in order to take no
chances I am sending in the morning Bustillo with two capataces
with authority to hire sufficient obreros there to fumigate with
canvas thoroughly the house in which the man was sick and the
surrounding dwellings.”-

The conclusions of Dr. Cartaya's report are
as follows:

“A case like the one described above, in which
during the first three days of illness temperatures taken in
axilla showed 39°, should have presented more marked icterus if
it were a case of yellow fever, more grave sysptoms and hemorr-
hages none of which have appeared.

But on the other hand a fever which ends or runs
its course in six or seven days, in which on the third and fourth
day (according to the chart) there is a dissociation between the
pulse and the temperature, accompanied by headache and general
pains, vomiting icteric tint (?) and a large amount of albumin,
must be regarded as suspicious and from a sanitary and prophylac-
tic standpoint should be treated as if it were yellow fever”.

I agred therefore with the Havana Commission in
recommending that all the prophylactic measures be carefully car-
ried out.

Dr. Fauntleroy informs me that Dr. Agostini reported
to him on September 24 that the case at Felton had been seen by
him and Dr. Carulla from its incipiency and had put it under a
mosquito bar. He and Dr. Carulla and Gomez saw it together on
the 22nd. and negatived it for yellow fever, considering it a-
cute nephritis after long exposure to water and wind. He, Dr.
Fauntleroy considered it negative for yellow fever after seeing
chart but ordered prophylactic measures to be taken.

The telegram of which I herewith enclose a copy
was sent to Dr. Thomason October 2nd..

Nothing suspicious has developed either in Havana
or in any other part of the Island. But the result of Dr. Agra-
monte's investigations at Cienfuegos where he was sent last Sun-
day has fully justified our suspicion that they were not so free
of mosquito breeding places as they had imagined. Agramonte ac-
companied by the local Inspector examined fifty seven houses in
seventeen of which larvae were found. I expect to have his writ-
ten report to day.

I fear that my correspondance on these dreary mat-
ters must be interfering with your enjoiment of the Congress and
of the amenities of the trip.

With kind regards to our friends in Washington
and kindest messages to you from Drs. Barnet and Lopez del Va-
lle, believe me my dear Major,
div1.closer:
Yours very sincerely, Carlos J. Finlay (3 enclosures).
JUNTA NACIONAL de SANIDAD
3-OCT 1903 008029
SALIDA
AL CONTESTAN, CONCIONALE PECHA F. NUMERO DE
ESTA COMUNICACION.
EN CADA SACRITO TRATASE DE UN SOLU ASUNTO
